headline.main: The Pill at 40: New Uses for a Drug That Changed Society

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on 40th anniversary of Food and Drug Administration approval of birth control pill; notes women can now choose from 59 different products, all variations on original theme; holds current formulations are remarkably safe; cites side effects and health benefits; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago today, the Food and Drug Administration approved a medication that set off a medical and social revolution. The medication was an oral contraceptive called Enovid, introduced in 1960 by Searle to a nation of women increasingly eager for greater certainty in preventing unwanted pregnancies. Though few realized it then, ''the Pill,'' as it came to be called, has turned out to have a number of ancillary health benefits as well as some serious side effects.
